1.text: Now concerning things sacrificed to idols: We know that we all have knowledge. Knowledge puffs up, but love builds up.

2.text: But if anyone thinks that he knows anything, he doesn’t yet know as he ought to know.

3.text: But if anyone loves God, the same is known by him.

4.text: Therefore concerning the eating of things sacrificed to idols, we know that no idol is anything in the world, and that there is no other God but one.

5.text: For though there are things that are called “gods,” whether in the heavens or on earth; as there are many “gods” and many “lords;”

6.text: yet to us there is one God, the Father, of whom are all things, and we for him; and one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom are all things, and we live through him.

7.text: However, that knowledge isn’t in all men. But some, with consciousness of the idol until now, eat as of a thing sacrificed to an idol, and their conscience, being weak, is defiled.

8.text: But food will not commend us to God. For neither, if we don’t eat, are we the worse; nor, if we eat, are we the better.

9.text: But be careful that by no means does this liberty of yours become a stumbling block to the weak.

10.text: For if a man sees you who have knowledge sitting in an idol’s temple, won’t his conscience, if he is weak, be emboldened to eat things sacrificed to idols?

11.text: And through your knowledge, he who is weak perishes, the brother for whose sake Christ died.

12.text: Thus, sinning against the brothers, and wounding their conscience when it is weak, you sin against Christ.

13.text: Therefore, if food causes my brother to stumble, I will eat no meat forevermore, that I don’t cause my brother to stumble.
